summary: This document is an email chain from August 2020 discussing the transfer and processing of digital evidence (thumb drives containing device extractions) related to the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The correspondence involves coordination between individuals to upload materials to the Relativity review platform and addresses questions about missing files, duplicate folders, and devices requiring hardware recovery.

persons.name: Francesco
persons.role: Potential point of contact for evidence coordination
persons.context: Mentioned as someone who might assist with outstanding evidence questions in the sender's absence.

events.title: Thumb drive return coordination
events.description: An individual states they have finished with a thumb drive containing evidence and will be returning it via FedEx from the White Plains office.

events.title: Planned mailing of evidence thumb drive
events.description: An email discusses plans to mail a thumb drive containing folders for five devices (NYCO24332, NYCO24369, NYCO24369 1, NYCO24372, NYCO24384) for processing and upload to Relativity.

events.title: Ongoing evidence processing and queries
events.description: A series of emails detail back-and-forth communication about the status of evidence extraction, including questions about missing items (NYC027913), duplicate folders, zero-byte files, and devices requiring hardware recovery.

keyFacts: The document is an email chain focused on the logistical coordination of digital evidence processing for the Ghislaine Maxwell case in August 2020.
Specific evidence device identifiers are discussed (e.g., NYCO24332, NYCO24369, NYC027913), indicating a structured inventory system for seized materials.
There is mention of devices requiring hardware recovery due to physical failure, suggesting some evidence was on damaged media.
The correspondence references uploading materials to 'Relativity', a commonly used e-discovery and document review platform.
A significant number (approximately 71,000) of zero-byte (empty) files were found in the initial seven devices provided, which was noted as potentially not unusual by the data recovery process.
